article.title: Dyslexia

preblock.preline: The cause of dyslexia is believed to involve bothgeneticsgeneticand environmental factors.Some cases run in families.It often occurs in people withattention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD) and is associated with similardyscalculiadifficulties with numbers.It may begin in adulthood as the result of atraumatic brain injury,stroke, ordementia.The underlying mechanisms are problems within thebrain's language processing.Dyslexia is diagnosed through a series of tests of memory, spelling, vision, and reading skills.cite webhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/reading/conditioninfo/pages/diagnosed.aspxHow are reading disorders diagnosed?National Institutes of Health15 March 2015Dyslexia is separate from reading difficulties caused by insufficientReading educationteaching; or either hearing or vision problems.

Treatment involves adjusting teaching methods to meet the person's needs.While not curing the underlying problem, it may decrease the degree of symptoms.cite webhttp://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/reading/conditioninfo/pages/treatment.aspxWhat are common treatments for reading disorders?National Institutes of Health15 March 2015Treatments targeting vision are not effective.cite journalHandlerSMFiersonWMSection onOphthalmologyCouncil on Children withDisabilitiesAmerican Academy ofOphthalmologyAmerican Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology andStrabismusAmerican Association of CertifiedOrthoptistsLearning disabilities, dyslexia, and vision.PediatricsMarch 20111273e818–562135734210.1542/peds.2010-3670Dyslexia is the most commonlearning disability,cite bookDarcy Ann UmphredRolando T. article.heading: Classification
article.paragraph: Dyslexia is thought to have two types of cause, one related toLanguage processing in the brainlanguage processingand another toVisual perceptionvisual processing.cite bookCampbellRobert JeanCampbell's Psychiatric Dictionaryhttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Oxford University Press978-0-19-534159-1310–312It is considered acognitive disorder, not a problem withintelligence, andEmotional and behavioral disordersemotional problemsoften arise because of it.Some published definitions are purely descriptive, whereas others propose causes. The latter usually cover a variety of reading skills and deficits, and difficulties with distinct causes rather than a single condition.cite journalLyytinenHeikkiIn Search of a Science Based Application:Learning Tool for Reading AcquisitionScandinavian Journal of PsychologyNovember 200950(6)6668–675http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1467-9450.2009.00791.x/full1993026810.1111/j.1467-9450.2009.00791.xTheNational Institute of Neurological Disorders and Strokedefinition describes dyslexia as "difficulty with spelling, phonological processing (the manipulation of sounds), or rapid visual-verbal responding".The British Dyslexia Association definition describes dyslexia as "a learning difficulty that primarily affects the skills involved in accurate and fluent word reading and spelling" and is characterized by "difficulties in phonological awareness, verbal memory and verbal processing speed".cite bookSylvia PhillipsKathleen KellyLiz SymesAssessment of Learners with Dyslexic-Type Difficultieshttp://books.google.com/books?id2013SAGE978-1-4462-8704-07

Acquired dyslexia or alexia may be caused by brain damage due tostrokeorcerebral atrophyatrophy.cite journalWoollamsAnna M.Connectionist neuropsychology: uncovering ultimate causes of acquired dyslexiaPhilosophical Translations of the Royal Society of London; Series B, Biological Sciences36916342012039824324241386642710.1098/rstb.2012.03989 December 2013http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/369/1634/20120398.long13 February 2015cite bookHeilmanKenneth M.ValensteinEdwardClinical Neuropsychologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-538487-1115–116Forms of alexia includepure alexia,surface dyslexia,semantic dyslexia,phonological dyslexia, anddeep dyslexia.cite bookMichael SpiveyMarc JoanisseKen McRaeThe Cambridge Handbook of Psycholinguisticshttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Cambridge University Press978-0-521-67792-9219–220
article.heading: Signs and symptoms
article.paragraph: See alsoCharacteristics of dyslexiaIn early childhood, symptoms that correlate with a later diagnosis of dyslexia includespeech delaydelayed onsetof speech, difficulty distinguishing left from right, difficulty with direction,cite journalHamada, Hiroshi; Tam, Patrick P.L.Mechanisms of left-right asymmetry and patterning: driver, mediator and responderF1000 Prime ReportsDecember 2014http://f1000.com/prime/reports/pubmed/2558026413 February 2015as well as being easily distracted by background noise.The reversal of letters or words andmirror writingare behaviors sometimes seen in people with dyslexia, but are not considered to be defining characteristics of the disorder.
Dyslexia andattention deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD) commonly occur together;about 15% of people with dyslexia also have ADHD and 35% of those with ADHD have dyslexia.

School-age dyslexic children may exhibit signs of difficulty in identifying or generating rhyming words, or counting the number of syllables in words both of which depend onphonological awareness.cite webDyslexia and Related DisordersJanuary 2003Alabama Dyslexia Association[[International Dyslexia Association]]29 April 2015http://idaalabama.org/Facts/Dyslexia_and_Related.pdfPDFThey may also show difficulty in segmenting words into individual sounds or may blend sounds when producing words, indicating reducedphonemic awareness.cite bookPeerLindsayReidGavinMultilingualism, Literacy and Dyslexiahttp://books.google.com/books?id2014Routledge978-1-136-60899-5219Difficulties with word retrieval or naming things is also associated with dyslexia.cite bookSally E. ShaywitzBennett A ShaywitzChapter 34 Making a Hidden Disability Visible: What Has Been Learned from Neurobiological Studies of DyslexiaH. Lee SwansonKaren R. HarrisSteve GrahamHandbook of Learning Disabilitieshttp://books.google.com/books?id22013Guilford Press978-1-4625-0856-3rp647Dyslexics are commonly poor spellers, a feature sometimes called dysorthographia ordysgraphia, which depends onOrthographyorthographic coding.

Problems persist into adolescence and adulthood and may accompany difficulties with summarizing stories, memorization, reading aloud, or learning foreign languages. Adult dyslexics can often read with good comprehension, though they tend to read more slowly than non-dyslexics and perform worse inspellingtests or when reading nonsense words a measure of phonological awareness.cite journalJarradLumProcedural learning is impaired in dyslexia: evidence from a meta-analysis of serial reaction time studiesResearch of Developmental DisabilitiesOctober 20133460–7623920029378496410.1016/j.ridd.2013.07.0173410

A common myth about dyslexia is that its defining feature is reading or writing letters or words backwards, but this is true of many children as they learn to read and write.cite webMyth 17: The Defining Feature of Dyslexia Is Reversing Lettershttp://www.psychologicalscience.org/media/myths/myth_17.cfmAssociation for psychological science15 March 2015

article.heading: Causes
article.paragraph: Image:Inferior parietal lobule - superior view animation.gifthumb300pxInferior parietal lobule ( superior view animation)some dyslexics demonstrate less electrical activation in this area.mainTheories of dyslexiaResearchers have been trying to find the neurobiological basis of dyslexia since the condition was first identified in 1881.cite bookGavin ReidAngela FawcettFrank Manis[[Linda Siegel]]The SAGE Handbook of Dyslexiahttp://books.google.com/books?id2008SAGE Publications978-1-84860-037-9127For example, some have tried to associate the common problem among dyslexics of not being able to see letters clearly to abnormal development of their visual nerve cells.cite journalJohnStein2014Dyslexia: the Role of Vision and Visual AttentionCurrent Developmental Disorders Reports14267–8025346883420399410.1007/s40474-014-0030-6
article.heading: Neuroanatomy
article.paragraph: MainNeurological research into dyslexiaModernneuroimagingtechniques such asfunctional magnetic resonance imaging(fMRI) andpositron emission tomography(PET) have shown a correlation between both functional and structural differences in the brains of children with reading difficulties.cite bookHarry A. WhitakerConcise Encyclopedia of Brain and Languagehttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Elsevier978-0-08-096499-7180Some dyslexics show less electrical activation in parts of the left hemisphere of the brain involved with reading, such as theinferior frontal gyrus,inferior parietal lobule, and the middle andBrodmann area 20ventral temporal cortex.Over the past decade, brain activation studies using PET to study language have produced a breakthrough in the understanding of the neural basis of language. Neural bases for the visuallexiconand for auditory verbalshort-term memorycomponents have been proposed,cite journalPricecathyA Review and Synthesis of the first 20 years of Pet and fMRI studies of heard Speech,Spoken Language and ReadingNeuroimageAugust 16, 201262(2)4816–84710.1016/j.neuroimage.2012.04.0623398395http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3398395/5 February 20153398395with some implication that the observed neural manifestation of developmental dyslexia is task-specific (i.e. functional rather than structural). fMRIs in dyslexics have provided important data which point to the interactive role of thecerebellumand cerebral cortex as well as other brain structures.cite journalSharifiSNeuroimaging essentials in essential tremor: a systematic review.Neuroimage ClinicalMay 2014217–23141103522506811110.1016/j.nicl.2014.05.0035cite journalBrandlerWilliamThe genetic relationship between handedness and neurodevelopmental disordersTrends in molecular medicineFebruary 201483–9039693002427532810.1016/j.molmed.2013.10.008202

The cerebellar theory of dyslexia proposes that impairment of cerebellum-controlled muscle movement affects the formation of words by the tongue and facial muscles, resulting in thefluencyproblems that are characteristic of some dyslexics. The cerebellum is also involved in theAutonomic nervous systemautomatizationof some tasks, such as reading.cite bookCainKateReading development and difficulties2010TJ International1341sthttp://books.google.com/?id21 March 20159781405151559The fact that some dyslexic children have motor task and balance impairments has been used as evidence for a cerebellar role in their reading difficulties. However, the cerebellar theory is not supported by controlled research studies.cite bookLevavItzhakPsychiatric and Behavioral Disorders in Israel: From Epidemiology to Mental health2009Green Publishing52http://books.google.com/?id21 March 20159789652294685

Abnormal cell formations in dyslexics have also been reported in non-language cerebral and subcortical brain structures.cite journalKereJuliaThe molecular genetics and neurobiology of developmental dyslexia as model of a complex phenotypeBiochemical and biophysical research communicationSeptember 2014236–43http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006291X1401351514 February 201510.1016/j.bbrc.2014.07.1024522Several genes have been associated with dyslexia, includingDCDC2andKIAA0319onchromosome 6,cite bookMarshall, Chloë R.Current Issues in Developmental Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Psychology Press978-1-136-23067-753–56andDYX1C1onchromosome 15.cite bookRosen, Glenn D.The Dyslexic Brain: New Pathways in Neuroscience Discoveryhttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Psychology Press1-134-81550-6342

article.heading: Mechanisms
article.paragraph: MainDual-route hypothesis to reading aloudThe dual-route theory ofReading (process)readingaloud was first described in the early 1970s.cite journalPritchard SC, Coltheart M, Palethorpe S, Castles ANonword reading: comparing dual-route cascaded and connectionist dual-process models with human dataJ Exp Psychol Hum Percept Perform3851268–88October 20122230908710.1037/a0026703ColtheartPalethorpeCastlesThis theory suggests that two separate mental mechanisms, or cognitive routes, are involved in reading aloud.cite bookMichael EysenckMark T. KeaneCognitive Psychology 6ehttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Psychology Press1-134-44046-4373One mechanism is the lexical route, which is the process whereby skilled readers can recognize known words by sight alone, through a "dictionary" lookup procedure.cite bookMichael EysenckMark T. KeaneCognitive Psychology 6ehttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Psychology Press1-134-44046-4450The other mechanism is the nonlexical or sublexical route, which is the process whereby the reader can "sound out" a written word.cite bookHulmeCharlesJoshiR. MalateshaSnowlingMargaret J.Reading and Spelling: Development and Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Routledge978-1-136-49807-7151This is done by identifying the word's constituent parts (letters,phonemes,graphemes) and applying knowledge of how these parts are associated with each other, for example, how a string of neighboring letters sound together.The dual-route system could explain the different rates of dyslexia occurrence between different languages (e.g. the Spanish language dependence on phonological rules accounts for the fact that Spanish-speaking children show a higher level of performance in non-word reading, when compared to English-speakers).cite journalSprenger-Charolles,LilianePrevalence and Reliability of Phonological, Surface, and Mixed Profiles in Dyslexia: A Review of Studies Conducted in Languages Varying in Orthographic DepthScientific studies of reading2011498–521http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/10888438.2010.524463#abstract11 March 201510.1080/10888438.2010.524463156

article.heading: Diagnosis
article.paragraph: There are tests that can indicate with high probability whether a person is a dyslexic.cite webhttp://dyslexiahelp.umich.edu/dyslexics/learn-about-dyslexia/dyslexia-testing/testsTests for Dyslexia and Learning DisabilitiesUniversity of Michigan15 March 2015If diagnostic testing indicates that a person may be dyslexic, such tests are often followed up with a full diagnostic assessment to determine the extent and nature of the disorder.cite bookLindsay PeerGavin ReidIntroduction to Dyslexiahttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Taylor & Francis978-1-135-37290-335–40Tests can be administered by a teacher or computer.Some test results indicate how to carry out teaching strategies.cite webScreening and assessmenthttp://www.bdadyslexia.org.uk/educator/screening-and-assessmentBritish Dyslexia Association11 March 2015cite journalFletcherJackDyslexia: the evolution of a scientific conceptJournal of international neuropsychology society2009501–50830793781957326710.1017/S1355617709090900154

article.paragraph: File:Broca's area - lateral view.pngthumbBroca's area (lateral view) dyslexics overuse this area which is associated with speechcite journalVandermostenMaaiketractography study in dyslexia: neuroanatomic correlates of orthographic, phonological and speech processingBrain13539352012http://brain.oxfordjournals.org/content/135/3/9354 March 201510.1093/brain/awr363MainPhonological dyslexiaIn phonological dyslexia, sufferers can read familiar words but have difficulty with unfamiliar words, such as invented pseudo-words.cite bookSusan AyersAndrew BaumChris McManusStanton NewmanKenneth WallstonJohn WeinmanRobert WestCambridge Handbook of Psychology, Health and Medicinehttp://books.google.com/books?id2007Cambridge University Press978-1-139-46526-7689Phonological dyslexia is associated with lesions in the parts of the brain supplied with blood by themiddle cerebral artery. The superior temporal lobe is often also involved. Furthermore, dyslexics compensate by overusing a front-brain region calledBroca's area, which is associated with aspects of language and speech.cite journalStefanHeimAnkeWehneltMarionGrandeWalterHuberKatrinAmuntsMay 2013Effects of lexicality and word frequency on brain activation in dyslexic readersBrain and Language1252194–2022223003910.1016/j.bandl.2011.12.005The Lindamood Phoneme Sequencing Program (LiPS) is used to treat phonological dyslexia.cite bookNancy MatherBarbara J. Case studies with a total of three patients found a significant improvement in spelling and reading ability after using LiPS.cite journalPélagie M.BeesonKindleRisingEsther S.KimSteven Z.RapcsakApril 2010A Treatment Sequence for Phonological Alexia/AgraphiaJournal of Speech, Language, and Hearing Research532450–6810.1044/1092-4388(2009/08-0229)203604663522177

article.heading: Pure dyslexia
article.paragraph: MainPure alexiaPure, or phonologically-based,cite bookBrownThomas E.ADHD Comorbidities: Handbook for ADHD Complications in Children and Adultshttp://books.google.com/books?id2009American Psychiatric Pub978-1-58562-158-3236dyslexia, also known as agnosic dyslexia, dyslexia without agraphia, and pure word blindness, is dyslexia due to difficulty in recognizing written sequences of letters (such as words), or sometimes even letters. It is considered '"pure" because it is not accompanied by other significant language-related impairments. Pure dyslexia does not affect speech, handwriting style, language or comprehension impairments.cite journalStarrfeltRandiÓlafsdóttirRannveig RósArendtIda-Marie2013Rehabilitation of pure alexia: A reviewNeuropsychological Rehabilitation235755–7923808895380542310.1080/09602011.2013.809661Pure dyslexia is caused by lesions on thevisual word form areavisual word form area (VWFA). The VWFA is composed of the leftlateral occipital sulcusand is activated during reading. A lesion in the VWFA stops transmission between thevisual cortexand the leftangular gyrus. It can also be caused by a lesion involving the leftoccipital lobeor thesplenium. It is usually accompanied by ahomonymous hemianopsiain the right side of the visual field.Multiple oral re-reading (MOR) is a treatment for pure dyslexia.cite bookArgye E. HillisThe Handbook of Adult Language Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Psychology Press1-134-94801-840It is considered a top-down processing technique in which affected individuals read and reread texts a predetermined number of times or until reading speed or accuracy improves a predetermined amount.cite bookIlias PapathanasiouPatrick CoppensConstantin PotagasAphasia and Related Neurogenic Communication Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Jones & Bartlett Publishers978-1-4496-8435-8168
article.heading: Hemianopic dyslexia
article.paragraph: Hemianopic dyslexia is commonly considered to derive fromvisual fieldloss due to damage to theprimary visual cortex.cite bookFrançois BollerJordan GrafmanHandbook of Neuropsychology: Disorders of visual behaviorhttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Gulf Professional Publishing978-0-444-50369-531Sufferers may complain of abnormally slow reading but are able to read individual words normally. This is the most common form of peripheral alexia, and the form with the best evidence of effective treatments.cite journalSchuettSusanne2009The rehabilitation of hemianopic dyslexiaNature Reviews Neurology58427–371958190110.1038/nrneurol.2009.97
article.heading: Neglect dyslexia
article.paragraph: In neglect dyslexia, some letters, most commonly those at the beginning or left side of a word, are skipped or misread during reading.cite bookMartha J. FarahGraham RatcliffThe Neuropsychology of High-level Visionhttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Psychology Press978-1-135-80652-1177–179This alexia is associated with right parietal lesions. The use of prism glasses has been shown to substantially mitigate this condition.Cite bookPsychology Around UsComerRonaldRR Donnelley2011978-0-471-38519-6232
article.heading: Attentional dyslexia
article.paragraph: People with attentional dyslexia complain of letter-crowding or migration, sometimes blending elements of two words into one.cite journalJean-MichelHSynaesthesia, subjective expression of a neuronal palimpsest?Medicine Sciences (in French)August 2012765–771http://www.microsofttranslator.com/bv.aspx?from13 February 2015Sufferers read better when words are presented in isolation rather than flanked by other words and letters. Using a large magnifying glass may help mitigate this condition by reducing the effects of flanking from nearby words; however, no trials of this or indeed any other therapy for left parietal syndromes have been published as of 2014.cite journalJohannaBogonKathrinFinkePriscaStenneken16 October 2014TVA-based assessment of visual attentional functions in developmental dyslexiaFrontiers in Psychology25360129419926210.3389/fpsyg.2014.0117251172
article.heading: Management

link.part: An example of OpenDyslexic typeface, which is used to mitigate common reading errors due to dyslexia.

article.paragraph: Through the use of compensation strategies, therapy and educational support, dyslexic individuals can learn to read and write.cite journalBogonJohanaTVA based assessment of visual attention functions in developmental dyslexiaFrontiers in PsychologyOctober 201441992622536012910.3389/fpsyg.2014.0117251172There are techniques and technical aids which help to manage or conceal symptoms of the disorder.cite bookNicola BrunswickSupporting Dyslexic Adults in Higher Education and the Workplacehttp://books.google.com/books?id10 April 201210 April 2012John Wiley & Sons978-0-470-97479-7115–Removing stress and anxiety alone can sometimes improve written comprehension.cite journalSchulte-KörneGThe prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of dyslexiaDtsch Arztebl IntOctober 2010718–2629677982104600310.3238/arztebl.2010.0718107412015-10-31Fordyslexia interventionwith alphabet-writing systems, the fundamental aim is to increase a child's awareness of correspondences betweengraphemes(letters) andphonemes(sounds), and to relate these to reading and spelling by teaching how sounds blend into words. It has been found that reinforced collateral training focused on reading and spelling yields longer-lasting gains than oral phonological training alone.Cite bookLyytinen, Heikki, Erskine, Jane, Aro, Mikko, Richardson, Ullahttp://books.google.com/books?idReading and reading disordersHoffErikaBlackwell Handbook of Language Development454–474Blackwell2009978-1-4051-9459-4Early intervention that done while the language areas of the brain are still developing is the most successful in reducing the long-term impacts of dyslexia. There is some evidence that the use of specially-tailored fonts may mitigate the effects of dyslexia.Cite journalRenskede LeeuwSpecial Font For Dyslexia?PDF[[University of Twente]]32December 2010English, Dutchhttp://www.ilo.gw.utwente.nl/ilo/attachments/032_Masterthesis_Leeuw.pdfhttp://liveweb.archive.org/http://www.ilo.gw.utwente.nl/ilo/attachments/032_Masterthesis_Leeuw.pdf1 November 2011noThese fonts, which includeDyslexie,OpenDyslexic, andLexia Readable, were created based on the idea that many of the letters of theLatin alphabetare visually similar and may therefore confuse dyslexics. Dyslexie and OpenDyslexic both put emphasis on making each letter more unique in order to be more easily identified.cite webSawersPaulDyslexie: A typeface for dyslexicshttp://thenextweb.com/shareables/2011/06/30/dyslexie-a-typeface-for-dyslexics/9 April 2012Font design can have an effect on reading, reading time, and the perception of legibility of all readers, not only those with dyslexia.cite webhttp://eida.org/3-things-to-know-about-dyslexic-fonts/3 Things to Know About Dyslexic Fonts28 February 2015International Dyslexia Association

There have been many studies conducted regarding intervention in dyslexia. Among these studies one meta-analysis found that there was functional activation as a result.cite journalBarqueroLauraNeuroimaging of reading interventionPLOS one201438883982442727810.1371/journal.pone.008366891e836682014PLoSO...983668B
article.heading: Prognosis
article.paragraph: Dyslexic children require special instruction for word analysis and spelling from an early age.cite journalO’HareAnneDyslexia: what do paediatricians need to know?Pediatrics and Child health2010338–343http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S175172221000095811 March 201510.1016/j.paed.2010.04.004207However, there are fonts that can help dyslexics better understand writing.The prognosis, generally speaking, is positive for individuals who are identified in childhood and receive support from friends and family.
article.heading: Epidemiology
article.paragraph: [[File:Types of writing systems.png|upright=1.3|thumb|Map showing predominant forms of writing systems by country and what their characters represent:Cite bookThe Semitic Languageshttps://books.google.com/books?idRoutledge2013-10-089781136115882RobertHetzronlegendblue[[Alphabet]] (consonants and vowels)legendgreen[[Abjad]] (only consonants)legend#e08040[[Abugida]] (family-related syllables)legendred[[Logogram]]slegendcyan[[Syllabary]] (isolated syllables)]]The percentage of people with dyslexia is unknown, but it has been estimated to be as low as 5% and as high as 17% of the population.Cite bookPsychiatry, 2 Volume Sethttps://books.google.com/books?idJohn Wiley & Sons2015-01-299781118845493AllanTasmanJeraldKayJeffrey A.LiebermanMichael B.FirstMichelleRibaWhile it is diagnosed more often in males,some believe that it affects males and females equally.

There are different definitions of dyslexia used throughout the world, but despite significant differences in writing systems, dyslexia occurs in different populations.cite journalProtopapasAthanassiosFrom temporal processing to developmental language disorders: mind the gapPhilosophical transactions of the Royal Sociey of LondonSeries B, Biological Sciences201324324245http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3866431/14 February 201510.1098/rstb.2013.00903866431369163420130090Dyslexia is not limited to difficulty in converting letters to sounds, and Chinese dyslexics may have difficulty convertingChinese charactersinto their meanings.cite journalZhaoJingThe visual magnocellular-dorsal dysfunction in Chinese children with developmental dyslexia impedes Chinese character recognition.Scientific reportsNovember 201442383002541238610.1038/srep07068470682014NatSR...4E7068Zcite bookChloe MarshallCurrent Issues in Developmental Disordershttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Psychology Press978-1-84872-084-8152The Chinese vocabulary uses logographic, monographic, non-alphabet writing where one character can represent an individual phoneme.Cite bookBrain, Mind, and Developmental Psychopathology in Childhoodhttp://books.google.com/?idJason Aronson2012-01-169780765708663ElenaGarraldaJean-PhilippeRaynaud

The phonological-processing hypothesis attempts to explain why dyslexia occurs in a wide variety of languages. Furthermore, the relationship between phonological capacity and reading appears to be influenced by orthography.Cite journalPhonological processing deficits as a universal model for dyslexia: evidence from different orthographieshttp://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?scriptCoDAS509–51926610.1590/2317-1782/2014201413525590915Ana Luiza Gomes PintoNavasÉrica de CássiaFerrazJuliana Postigo AmorinaBorgesAna Luiza Gomes PintoNavasÉrica de CássiaFerrazJuliana Postigo AmorinaBorges2014
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: MainHistory of developmental dyslexiaDyslexia was identified byOswald Berkhanin 1881,Cite journalBerkhan O1917Über die Wortblindheit, ein Stammeln im Sprechen und Schreiben, ein Fehl im LesenAbout word blindness, adyslalia of speech and writing, a weakness in readingGermanNeurologisches Centralblatt36914–27http://books.google.com/?idbut the termdyslexiawas coined in 1887 byRudolf Berlin, anophthalmologistinStuttgart.Cite journal''Über Dyslexie''About dyslexia1884Archiv für Psychiatrie15276–278He used the term to refer to the case of a young boy who had a severe impairment in learning to read and write, despite showing typical intelligence and physical abilities in all other respects.cite bookAnnual of the Universal Medical Sciences and Analytical Index: A Yearly Report of the Progress of the General Sanitary Sciences Throughout the Worldhttp://books.google.com/books?id1888F. A. Davis Company39In 1896, W. Pringle Morgan, a British physician fromSeaford, East Sussex, published a description of a reading-specific learning disorder in a report to theBritish Medical Journaltitled "Congenital Word Blindness".cite bookBrooksPatriciaEncyclopedia of language development2014SAGE30http://books.google.com/?id4 March 20159781483346434The distinction between phonological and surface types of dyslexia is only descriptive, and without any etiological assumption as to the underlying brain mechanisms. However, studies have alluded to potential differences due to variation in performance.cite journalMishraSrikanta K.Medial efferent mechanisms in children with auditory processing disorders.Frontiers in human neuroscienceOctober 201425386132http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4209830/14 February 201510.3389/fnhum.2014.0086042098308860
article.heading: Research and society
article.paragraph: MainDyslexia researchThe majority of currently available dyslexia research relates toWriting systemalphabetic writing systems, and especially toLanguages of EuropeEuropean languages.cite bookReidGavinThe Routledge Companion to Dyslexiahttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Routledge978-1-136-61710-216However, substantial research is also available regarding dyslexics who speak Arabic, Chinese, Hebrew or other languages.cite journalRichlanFabioFunctional neuroanatomy of developmental dyslexia; the role of orthographic depthFrontiers in human neuroscienceMay 201424904383http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4033006/14 February 201510.3389/fnhum.2014.0034740330068347

As is the case with any disorder, society often makes an assessment based on incomplete information. Before the 1980s, dyslexia was thought to be a consequence of education, rather than a basic disability. As a result, society often misjudges those afflicted with the disorder.cite journalKorneGerdThe prevention diagnosis and treatment of dyslexiaDeutches International2010718–72729677982104600310.3238/arztebl.2010.0718107412015-10-31There is also sometimes a workplace stigma and negative attitude towards those with dyslexia.cite journalde BerrJFactors influencing work participation of adults with developmental dyslexiaBMC Public Health201439130082446094910.1186/1471-2458-14-771477If a dyslexic's instructors lack the necessary training to support a child with the condition, there is often a negative effect on the student's learning participation.Cite journalThe Inclusion of Students with Dyslexia in Higher Education: A Systematic Review Using Narrative Synthesishttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4253321/Dyslexia (Chichester, England)2014-11-01425332125293652346–36920410.1002/dys.1484MarcoPinoLuiginaMortariThere is no evidence demonstrating that the use of music education is effective in improving dyslexic adolescents' reading skills.Cite bookMusic education for improving reading skills in children and adolescents with dyslexiahttp://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD009133.pub2/abstractJohn Wiley & Sons, Ltd2012-08-1510.1002/14651858.cd009133.pub2/abstracttrueHugoCogo-MoreiraRégis BAndrioloLatifeYazigiGeorge BPloubidisClara ReginaBrandão de ÁvilaJair JMari
